questions.text: The criminal responsibility of mentally ill person is dealt under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The criminal responsibility of mentally ill person is dealt under Sec. 22 of BNS

Sec. 20 BNS (Section 82 IPC) : Act of a child under seven years of age.-Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.

Sec. 22 BNS (Section 84 IPC) : Act of a person of unsound mind.-Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

Sec. 23 BNS (Section 85 IPC) : Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will. An act is not an offense if, at the time of committing it, a person was so intoxicated that they couldn't understand what they were doing or that it was wrong-provided the intoxication was involuntary, i.e., the substance was administered without their knowledge or against their will.

Sec. 24 BNS (Section 86 IPC): Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated.-If an act is only considered criminal when committed with a specific intent or knowledge, a person who does it while intoxicated will be treated by law as if they had the same intent as when sober-unless the intoxication was involuntary, meaning the substance was given without their knowledge or consent.

questions.text: Which rule denotes that "To establish a defence on the ground of insanity, it must be clearly shown that at the time of committing the act, the accused was labouring under such a defect of reason, from disease of mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing or, if he did know it, that he did not know that what he was doing was wrong."?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

McNaughton's rule: Presumption of sanity: Everyone is assumed to be mentally sound unless proven otherwise.To claim insanity as a defense, it must be clearly shown that at the time of the act-The person was suffering from a mental illness or defect that affected their ability to think clearly, and Because of that condition, they either didn't understand what they were doing, or even if they did, they didn't realize it was wrong (either legally or morally)

Durham's rule (Option B): An accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental Disease or mental Defect.

Currens rule (Option C): An accused is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, the defendant, as a result of mental disease or defect, lacks substantial Capacity to Conform his Conduct to the requirements of law.

American law institute (ALI) test (Option D): A person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, as a result of mental disease or defect lacked substantial capacity either to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient is brought for medical examination for alleged assault of his neighbour. On examination, abnormal behaviour with irrelevant talk is noted. He has history of abstaining from alcohol for past 4 days and is diagnosed to be a case of delirium tremens. What is true according to the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Delirium tremens is a psychiatric condition arising as a result of abstinence from alcohol. In case of delirium tremens, he doesn't know what he is doing. So, he is not criminally responsible for his act under section 22 BNS.

Sec. 22 BNS: Act of a person of unsound mind. Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: A criminal act done under impulse is not punishable under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Irresistible impulse test (New Hampshire doctrine): If a person, due to a mental disease, knows what they're doing is wrong but cannot control their actions because their free will has been overwhelmed by that disease, they're not criminally responsible.

American law institute (ALI) test (Option A): A person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, as a result of mental disease or defect lacked substantial capacity either to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law.

Durham's rule (Option C): An accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental Disease or mental Defect.

Currens rule (Option D): An accused is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, the defendant, as a result of mental disease or defect, lacks substantial Capacity to Conform his Conduct to the requirements of law.

Explanation:

Lucid interval is a brief period of regained consciousness between two phases of unconsciousness seen in both Head injury and Mental illness

Lucid Interval in Psychiatry (Mental Illness)

  • A temporary phase during a mental illness when all psychiatric symptoms vanish, enabling clear judgment.
  • The individual becomes legally responsible for their actions during this period.
  • Duration of lucid intervals varies widely between individuals and even between episodes in the same person.
  • Uncertainty in timing-it's extremely difficult to determine whether the person was mentally abnormal at the moment of the offense.
  • As a result, full legal responsibility may be contested, since the person's mental state at the exact time of the offense is unclear.
  • Lucid intervals occur commonly in conditions like mania and melancholia.

Lucid Interval in Head Injury (Extradural Hematoma; EDH)

  • Refers to a brief period of regained consciousness between two phases of unconsciousness-commonly seen in epidural (extradural) hematomas.
  • Classic pattern: initial loss of consciousness → lucid interval → rapid neurological decline.
  • The lucid interval can last from minutes to hours.
  • Prevalence is up to ~20-50% of EDH cases.
  • Caused by arterial (rapid) or venous (slower) bleeding, which expands and raises intracranial pressure, leading to stupor or coma
  • This presentation is notorious as the "talk-and-die" scenario-initially alert, followed by critical deterioration.

questions.text: Under the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017, which provision allows a mentally ill individual to designate their preferred caretaker or decision-maker for mental health-related decisions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Advance Directive: Every person, who is not a minor, have a right to make an advance directive in writing, specifying:

  1. The way the person wishes to be cared or not to be cared for and treated for a mental illness.
  2. The individual or individuals, in order of precedence, he wants to appoint as his nominated representative.

Advance medical directive (also called living will) (Option B): The Supreme court has recognised Advance medical directive (also called living will). It is the direction given by an adult in his conscious mind that, in future if he/she becomes terminally ill and becomes an incompetent patient whether to give medical treatment or not.

Testamentary capacity (Testament = will) (Option C): It is the mental ability of a person to make a valid will.

To make a valid Will, it should have following components:

  • He should be major.
  • The person should be of sound mind.
  • The person making Will should understand the nature of Will.
  • The person should have knowledge of his property that has to be disposed of.
  • The person should recognize the individuals who have moral claims to heir his property.

Palliative care (Option D): It is specialized medical care that focuses on providing relief from pain and other symptoms of a serious illness.

questions.text: A magistrate can pass an order for admission of a neglected mentally ill person for assessment for a maximum period of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 102 of Mental health care Act 2017:

  1. When any person with mental illness or who may have a mental illness appears or is brought before a Magistrate, the Magistrate may, order in writing-
    1. that the person is conveyed to a public mental health establishment for assessment and treatment, if necessary and the mental health establishment shall deal with such person in accordance with the provisions of the Act; or
    2. to authorise the admission of the person with mental illness in a mental health establishment for such period not exceeding ten days to enable the medical officer or mental health professional in charge of the mental health establishment to carry out an assessment of the person and to plan for necessary treatment, if any.
  2. On completion of the period of assessment, the medical officer or mental health professional in charge of the mental health establishment shall submit a report to the Magistrate and the person shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of this Act

questions.text: Mental retardation is defined when I.Q. is less than
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mental Retardation is presently known as Intellectual disability (ID), also called intellectual development disorder (IDD) or general learning disability.When a person has an IQ score below about 70, which means their ability to learn, reason, and solve problems is much lower than average. This typically affects their ability to manage everyday tasks and appears early in life.
